Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC FRP: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Research in Visualization-based Gap Analysis and Link Prediction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed Visualization-Based Gap Analysis effort is aimed at providing an intuitive visualization and analysis techniques to provide analysts with the ability to understand what has happened within a domain, comprehend its current status and operations, and explore the impact of changes to the system. Link
Discovery is seeking to automatically predict what relations arise in the future between objects. The proposed research intends to reformulate the link discovery problem to include predicting the strength of the link as well as create techniques to detect and predict special categories of future links; such links that arise that bridge two dense clusters of objects. Link prediction for domains other than social media and specialized literature domains will be explored.

Predictive analysis to determine future events in an industry environment based on current and past data represents an outcome of tremendous economic and societal impact. Through establishment of more rigorous capabilities for Visual Gap Analysis and Link Discovery, industry may be better able to understand what has happened, comprehend what is the current state, and obtain some grasp of what is likely to happen, may be greatly enhanced increasing productivity and allowing focus on problem resolution. The proposed effort is supported by the Industry Advisory Board and will engage individual center members. Graduate students will be trained through the research and results will be integrated into courses and industry seminars and short courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graphs are a very versatile tool for representing data; it allows for different types of entities (people, web pages, sales items, etc.) to be represented as different types of nodes and the different relationships to be modeled as links. Graphs have been used to aid activities such as item recommendation (Amazon), Web Search (Google, Bing), social media analysis (LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter), and so forth.

The collaborative effort between the University of Louisiana at Lafayette (UL Lafayette) and Drexel University (Drexel) was designed to enhance two complimentary approaches in graph analytics: link discovery and visualization-based gap analysis. Link discovery seeks to predict what links (relationships) will form between nodes (entities) in the future that are not currently present and to predict which currently existing links will disappear. Visualization-based gap analysis seeks to provide tools to visually present the data, and along with underlying analytical models, allow users to understand what has happened within a domain, comprehend the current status, and explore the impact of changes to the current system (graph). Ideally, link discovery would allow us to predict what changes will occur, in terms of links, and the visualization-based gap analysis would allow users to understand the impacts of those changes.

UL Lafayette led the link discovery research and Drexel led the visualization-based gap analysis research. With respect to the link discovery effort, UL Lafayette accomplished three major goals. First, we demonstrated that a link discovery method, designed to search a biomedical database and to suggest new potential research via the linking of concepts that were currently separate could be used in other domains. In particular, we used the same method as part of a news web page recommendation system; it predicted which news articles a user would select next. We also showed that the same method could be used to conduct social media analysis; in this case, we successfully applied the method to detect drug side effects and label them as adverse or non-adverse.

Second, we developed a means to consistently rank predicted links based upon how interesting they were. For large datasets, such as a social network, people are connecting and forming links all the time. In this context, if two people have 30 professional contacts in common, it may not be surprising that they eventually become co-workers; however, if a link is predicted between two people having only a few common contacts then that link is deemed as more interesting. Our approach allows the incorporation of a number of factors that permit us to predict and present only interesting future links or relationships.

Third, we extended the method to allow for the prediction of what type of link would be formed in the future. For the drug reaction problem, this would be if the relationship is adverse (drug causes a negative reaction) or non-adverse. For social media, this could be co-worker, friend, family, and so forth. 

As a result of these modifications, we have a method that can be applied to several different domains or problems such as sales recommendation systems, social networks, literature analysis, etc. This is significant, as most link discovery systems are designed for only specific problems. Moreover, most systems only predict new links. Our method can predict new links as well as the type of link and how interesting/useful the new link will be. Hence, people using the system will be in a much better position to decide whether to act upon the predictions; in the absence of new capabilities created by our research, they would have had to spend quite a bit of time determining if knowing about the new link is even useful.
